title: Black Friday
task_instruction: Read the text about Black Friday in America. For questions 1-10, choose the correct answer based on the text.

passages.title: America's Biggest Shopping Day
passages.text: The day after Thanksgiving has become America's biggest shopping day. Closed all day on Thursday, shopping centres all across the nation open early on Friday. Some of them open at 12:01 Friday morning, while others open at 4 a.m. Some 'sleepyhead' shopping centres, like Target this year, don't open their doors on Friday until 6 a.m. From Friday to the day before Christmas, this is the season when businesses make nearly 25 per cent of what they earn in a year. This season puts many businesses 'in the black', that is, they make the money they need for the year.

passages.title: Eager Shoppers
passages.text: Reporters from local TV stations interview people who sleep in tents in front of the shops a day or two before the doors open on Friday. These people patiently wait in queue to get products that are 50 per cent cheaper or more. 'Oh, we have fun,' said one of the persons queuing. 'We sometimes bring games to play, we watch TV and order lots of pizza, and we often meet interesting people. And, most important of all, we save a lot!' The problem, of course, is that only a very small number of products have big reductions in their prices. Apart from a few big discounts, each shop has other things that are reduced from 10 to 50 per cent, saving shoppers from $10 to $400 per item, and so Americans want to go shopping.

passages.title: Criticism of Black Friday
passages.text: Not all Americans enjoy shopping. Reverend William Graham wants to change Black Friday's name. 'We want to call it Remember Jesus Friday. People should start the season with the right attitude. Christmas has become a Season of Shopping. We want to make it a Season of Giving. And we don't mean giving material things. We mean giving your back, your mind, and your hands. Help an old lady clean up her house. Teach a kid how to read. Visit sick people in the hospital or in nursing homes. Give food to the Red Cross. Celebrate Christmas by remembering Jesus and forgetting Santa Claus.'

questions.question: When does Black Friday happen?
questions.explanation: The text begins by stating 'The day after Thanksgiving has become America's biggest shopping day.'

questions.question: What time do some stores open on Black Friday?
questions.explanation: Some stores open 'at 12:01 Friday morning' while others open later.

questions.question: What does 'in the black' mean for businesses?
questions.explanation: The text explains this means 'they make the money they need for the year.'

questions.question: How do some shoppers prepare for Black Friday?
questions.explanation: People 'sleep in tents in front of the shops a day or two before' to wait in line.

questions.question: What do shoppers NOT mention doing while waiting in line?
questions.explanation: They mention games, TV and pizza, but not online shopping while waiting.

questions.question: What percentage discount do most Black Friday products offer?
questions.explanation: Apart from a few big discounts, most items are 'reduced from 10 to 50 per cent.'

questions.question: What does Reverend Graham want to change about Black Friday?
questions.explanation: He wants to 'change Black Friday's name' to 'Remember Jesus Friday.'

questions.question: What does Reverend Graham suggest people should give?
questions.explanation: He means 'giving your back, your mind, and your hands' through service.

questions.question: Which activity does Reverend Graham NOT mention as good giving?
questions.explanation: All other options are mentioned except buying material presents.

questions.question: What is the main criticism of Christmas in the text?
questions.explanation: The reverend criticizes that 'Christmas has become a Season of Shopping.'
